awd_titl_txt: Probabilistic Methods in Geometry and Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Stochastic processes such as Brownian motion appear in many fields of science and applications.  They are used to model complex systems in biology, financial markets, and social networks. In many cases the system has natural constraints which can be described as an underlying  geometric structure. This project is devoted to a study of such stochastic processes, and how their properties reflect their geometric or structural environment. Sometimes the space on which the stochastic processes live is assumed to be not just curved, but infinite-dimensional, which is a natural setting for many physical or large data environments. 


This project includes several directions combining probability, geometry, analysis and representation theory. One of the directions of research is to study Cameron-Martin type quasi-invariance in elliptic and subelliptic settings, and its applications to functional inequalities, smoothness of probability laws for subelliptic and singular diffusions, and unitary representations of infinite-dimensional groups such as path groups. Another direction is applying coupling techniques to hypoelliptic stochastic processes, including gradient estimates and connections with geometric and analytic techniques for hypoelliptic diffusions. Some of the proposed research is motivated by physics, especially the quantum field theory (QFT), as infinite-dimensional spaces such as loop groups and path spaces appear in the QFT.

por.por_cntn:
The project involved different topics in stochastic and geometric analysis. Some of the results were on hypoelliptic second differential operators coming from sub-Riemannian geometry and satisfying a weak Hormander's condition.  These settings appear in many applications such as mechanics and physics. The probabilistic techniques developed by the PI with her collaborators have led to new results in analysis and probability incluidng regularity of the corresponding parabolic equations. Some of the results concerned metric geometry with applications in geometric analysis. Another project studied infinite-dimensional processes which are non-linear perturbations of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process.  The PI with her collaborators introduced a new notion of solutions to such equations and studied their properties. This approach in particular led to a natural candidate for an entropy which will be the suject of study in the future.

The broader impacts included numerous conference presentations by the PI, her collaborators and her PhD students. One of the talks by the PI was given at a conference on undergraduate research. The grant supported several of PI's graduate students. One of them graduated in this period and continued on to an academic position at Purdue. One of PI's PhD studens mentored projects with undergraduate students participating in UConn's REU. This resulted in publications. The students presented their results at conferences.
